questions.text: At a regular visit at 6 weeks of age, the mother complaints about a large hard bump along the middle of the bone at the top of the chest on right side in her baby. According to her, the baby is mobbing both the arms with same range of movements. Child was born full term with large for gestational age. No NICU stay was needed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the abnormality prompting the mother's concern?
questions.solution:
• Large for gestational age is a risk factor for birth trauma like Clavicular fracture, Erb's palsy, shoulder dislocation, Klumpke's paralysis.
  • Here, the range of movement are normal. Hence nerve damage and shoulder dislocation are ruled out.
  • Location of swelling is suggestive of fracture at the medial end of clavicle.
  • Potter syndrome is associated with oligohydramnios having typical facial features and renal failure.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 331

choices.text: Broad nasal bridge, cleft palate, microcephaly
Short palpebral fissures, midface hypoplasia, smooth philtrum, thin superior vermillion border

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities are consistent with fetal alcohol syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Characteristics of fetal alcohol syndrome include

(a) prenatal onset and persistence of growth deficiency for length, weight, and head circumference;

(b) facial abnormalities, including short palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, maxillary hypoplasia, micrognathia, smooth philtrum, and a thin, smooth upper lip;

(c) cardiac defects, primarily septal defects;

(d) minor joint and limb abnormalities, including some restriction of movement and altered palmar crease patterns; and

(e) delay of development and mental deficiency varying from borderline to severe. Fetal alcohol syndrome is a common identifiable cause of mental retardation.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 895

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl visits you with her mother for routine checkup. She has not visited you since she was 9-year-old. Before that time, she had been seen regularly and had been up to date on all the immunizations. On physical examination, her vitals are stable and her examination is normal. Which of the following vaccinations must be offered to her during her visit?
questions.solution:
• Tdap is recommended at 10 completed years of age.
  • HPV is given after 9 completed years thru 45 years
  • Seasonal influenza vaccine is recommended once every year, preferably pre monsoon.
  • At the first point of contact all these vaccines must be counselled to catch up with lates immunizations. All these can be given together without any cross reaction.

Reference: IAP textbook of immunization

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is presented with 2 days fever and headache. He has been vomiting today and is lying around complaining of feeling tired. There are no respiratory symptoms. Vitals are, Temperature-104F, HR 105/min, BP 112/80 mmHg, Respiratory rate 16/min. On examination, you notice an ill appearing and somnolent young child. His distal pulses are strong and capillary refill is normal. He has no focal neurological deficit but mild nuchal rigidity is present. He has a blanching macular rash on distal extremities which is absent on head and trunk. Which of the following is the least important to include in your initial management?
questions.solution:
• The child has signs and symptoms suggestive of Meningitis. Rash mentioned here is more suggestive of Viral origin over Meningococcal rash. Meningococcal rash is non blanching and develops on palms and soles more commonly.
  • In any case, any child with suspected meningitis needs vitals to be monitored, Lumbar puncture done before IV antibiotics are given and Antibiotics must be started before receiving the results of CSF examination.
  • CT head is not of much help as it does not add any extra information for immediate management.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1361

questions.text: Antibiotic of choice to cover organism responsible for Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever?
questions.solution:
• The time-proven effective therapies for RMSF are tetracyclines and chloramphenicol.
  • The treatment of choice for suspected RMSF in patients of all ages, including for young children, is doxycycline (4 mg/kg/day divided every 12 hours PO or IV; maximum: 200 mg/day).
  • Tetracycline (25-50 mg/kg/day divided every 6 hours PO; maximum: 2 g/day) is an alternative.
  • Chloramphenicol (50-100 mg/kg/day divided every 6 hours IV; maximum: 4 g/day) should be reserved for patients with doxycycline allergy and for pregnant women.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 1502

choices.text: The peak age for both is same
GI involvement in IgA vasculitis is severe and may lead to intussusception

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding IgA vasculitis and Kawasaki disease?
questions.solution:
• Gastrointestinal manifestations of HSP occur in up to 80% of children with HSP and include abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, paralytic ileus and melena; intussusception, mesenteric ischemia, intestinal perforations are uncommon.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 1216

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with a few focal areas of asymptomatic scalp alopecia associated with mild scale and black dots. The lesions have been present for several weeks. He also has posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this scalp eruption?
questions.solution:
• tonsurans causes Tinea Capitis.
  • Endothrix infections such as those caused by tonsurans create a pattern known as 'black-dot ringworm,' characterized initially by many small circular patches of alopecia in which hairs are broken off close to the hair follicle.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 3214

choices.text: Repeat morning testing and renal ultrasound
Water deprivation test and brain MRI if responsive to vasopressin
Oral glucose tolerance test and screening for autoimmune disease

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl developed increased thirst and polyuria abruptly over 2 weeks. She is constantly thirsty and becomes angry when fluids are not readily available. She has also begun wetting the bed after being dry for 2 years. Initial screening tests include serum Na 150 meq/L, K 4.5 meq/L, bicarbonate 28 mmol/L, Cl 110 meq/L, BUN 10 mg/dl, Ca 9.5 mg/dl, Ca 9.5 mg/dl and glucose 80 mg/dl. Serum osmolality is measured at 295 mosm/L. Osmolality of a first morning void of urine is 100 mosm/L. What further tests should be completed to confirm the diagnosis and determine possible cause?
questions.solution:
• If pathologic polyuria or polydipsia is present, the following should be obtained: serum for osmolality, sodium, potassium, blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, glucose, and calcium; urine for osmolality, specific gravity, and glucose determination.
  • The diagnosis of DI is established if the serum osmolality is >300 mOsm/kg and the urine osmolality is <300 mOsm/kg. DI is unlikely if the serum osmolality is <270 mOsm/kg or the urine osmolality is >600 mOsm/kg. If the patient's serum osmolality is <300 mOsm/kg (but >270 mOsm/kg) and pathologic polyuria and polydipsia are present, a water deprivation test is indicated to establish the diagnosis of DI and to differentiate central from nephrogenic causes.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2645

questions.text: Galactosemia is inherited as autosomal recessive fashion. What is the risk of galactosemia in a child whose parents are both carriers for the disorder?
questions.solution:
• In any autosomal recessive disorder with both parent's carrier of the disease:
  • Children being carrier: 50%
  • Children normal: 25%
  • Children affected: 25%

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 580

questions.text: A child presents with lymphedema of the hands and feet, a shield shaped chest, widely spaced hypoplastic nipples, short stature, and multiple pigmented nevi. In addition, she had a coarctation of aorta that was repaired and also has renal disease. Which of the following chromosomal disorders is most likely in this child?
questions.solution:
• Characteristics of Turner syndrome include:
    • Webbing of the neck, a low posterior hairline, small mandible, prominent ears, epicanthal folds, high arched palate, a broad chest presenting the illusion of widely spaced nipples, cubitus valgus, and hyperconvex fingernails. The diagnosis is often first suspected at puberty when breast development fails to occur.
    • Cardiac lesions are bicuspid aortic valve, ascending aortic dilation, coarctation of the aorta, and partial anomalous pulmonary venous connections, are present in patients with Turner syndrome.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2744

questions.text: A 12-month-old child presents with a Hb 7.5 g/dl, Hct 22%, MCV 65 fL, adjusted reticulocyte count is 1%. What is the most likely cause of this anemia?
questions.solution:
• Iron deficiency anemia has low Hct, low MCV, normal/increased retic count; microcytic hypochromic anemia
  • Anemia of chronic disease is normocytic normochromic
  • Aplastic crisis has pancytopenia with normal/raised MCV
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency has raised MCV.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2323

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency room tor gross hematuria of 1 day. He also has had decreased appetite and energy levels for the past 2 days. No fever or vomiting, but had been ill about 3 weeks ago with 1 day of fever and abdominal pain. Vitals are, Temperature 98.5F, HR 82 beats per minute (bpm) and blood pressure 120/80 mm Hg. He has some eyelid swelling and pretibial edema. His urine dipstick results show 4+ blood and 2+ protein. Microscopic examination confirms the presence of red cells in the urine, along with some red cell casts and 20-25 pus cells. Serum electrolytes are within normal limits, but creatinine is slightly elevated at 0.7 mg/dl. Which of the following represents the most appropriate next laboratory test?
questions.solution:
• The child in the vignette has hypertension, hematuria, proteinuria, edema. There is a preceding history of illness before 3 weeks. These are suggestive of PSGN.
  • Urinalysis demonstrates red blood cells, often in association with red blood cell casts, proteinuria, and polymorphonuclear leukocytes. A mild normochromic anemia may be present from hemodilution and low-grade hemolysis. The serum C3 level is significantly reduced in >90% of patients in the acute phase, and returns to normal 6-8 week after onset. Although serum CH50 is commonly depressed, C4 is most often normal in APSGN, or only mildly depressed.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2498

questions.text: A newborn infant is found at birth to have proximal hypospadias in a short phallus with bilateral nonpalpable gonads. The karyotype is suggestive of XX and the 17-hydroxyprogesterone is elevated. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The child in the vignette has hypertension, hematuria, proteinuria, edema. There is a preceding history of illness before 3 weeks. These are suggestive of PSGN.
  • Urinalysis demonstrates red blood cells, often in association with red blood cell casts, proteinuria, and polymorphonuclear leukocytes. A mild normochromic anemia may be present from hemodilution and low-grade hemolysis. The serum C3 level is significantly reduced in >90% of patients in the acute phase, and returns to normal 6-8 week after onset. Although serum CH50 is commonly depressed, C4 is most often normal in APSGN, or only mildly depressed.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2498

questions.text: One Infant girl has very low muscle tone and requires nasogastric tube feeding, as she cannot feed from a bottle. You have tried everything-with no success, and a gastrostomy tube is being considered. On examination she has up slanting almond-shaped eyes and small hands and feet. Which of the following would be the most likely diagnosis in this Infant?
questions.solution:
• Severe hypotonia and feeding difficulties at birth, voracious appetite and obesity in infancy, short stature (responsive to growth hormone), small hands and feet, hypogonadism, intellectual disability.
  • Angelman has similar presentation but short stature and small hands and feet goes in favor of Prader-Willi.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 602

questions.text: 18-month-old boy's father Is concerned about his child's development in relation to his two older brothers. The boy avoids eye contact and does not respond to efforts to engage him in reciprocal play such as peek-a-boo and patty cake games. He does not generate spontaneous language but can repeat certain words if spoken to him over and over. He spends a lot of time by himself rocking back and forth and becomes very agitated If this activity Is Interrupted. Which of the following conditions Is most consistent with this child's reported behaviors?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis criteria for Autism:

  1. Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction across multiple contexts, as manifested by the following, currently or by history:
    1. Deficits in social-emotional reciprocity.
    2. Deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors used for social interaction.
    3. Deficits in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships.
  2. Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities, as manifested by at least two of the following, currently or by history:
    1. Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, use of objects, or speech.
    2. Insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines, or ritualized patterns of verbal or nonverbal behavior.
    3. Highly restricted, fixated interests that are abnormal in intensity or focus.
    4. Hyper- or hypo reactivity to sensory input or unusual interest in sensory aspects of the environment.
  3. Symptoms must be present in the early developmental period (may not become fully manifest until social demands exceed limited capacities, or may be masked by learned strategies in later life).
  4. Symptoms cause clinically significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of current functioning.
  5. These disturbances are not better explained by intellectual disability (intellectual developmental disorder) or global developmental delay.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 177

questions.text: An unvaccinated 5-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of fever and respiratory distress. On physical examination, the girl appears toxic, is drooling, and leaning forward with her chin extended. She has a temperature of 104°F (40°C) and a respiratory rate of 32 breaths per minute. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Fever, toxic child and drooling with acute onset of respiratory distress is suggestive of Epiglottitis. Most common organism responsible is H. influenza against which child is not protected as he is unvaccinated.
  • Closest differential is croup, where barking cough is initial symptom with fever, but child is not toxic.
  • Any child with epiglottitis must be intubated to avoid sudden choking due to large airway edema.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2032

questions.text: You see a 4-year-old child for declining school performance and behavior problems. His mother notes that he is a poor sleeper. He snores loudly and often gasps in his sleep. You note a slight fall off the growth curve and very large tonsils. A neck film demonstrates large adenoids as well. What is gold standard to diagnose obstructive sleep apnea?
questions.solution:
• No combination of clinical history and physical findings can accurately predict which children with snoring have OSA, the gold standard for diagnosing OSA remains an in-lab overnight

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 116

questions.text: Which of the following condition(s) is (are) often associated with polyhydramnios?
questions.solution:
• Congenital anomalies:
    • Anencephaly
    • Hydrocephaly
    • Tracheoesophageal fistula
    • Duodenal atresia
    • Spina bifida
    • Cleft lip or palate
    • Cystic adenomatoid lung malformation
    • Diaphragmatic hernia
  • Syndromes:
    • Achondroplasia
    • Klippel-Feil
    • Trisomy 18
    • Trisomy 21
  • TORCH (toxoplasmosis, other agents, rubella, cytomegalovirus, herpes simplex)
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Multiple congenital anomalies
  • Other:
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Twin-twin transfusion (recipient)
    • Fetal anemia
    • Fetal heart failure
    • Polyureic renal disease
    • Neuromuscular diseases
    • Nonimmune hydrops
    • Chylothorax
    • Teratoma
    • Idiopathic

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 803

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to your office complaining of progressive fatigue, weakness, and nausea over the past few months. He was a model student, but he is now having trouble in school and displaying frequent outbursts, the last of which resulted in his being sent home for hitting another child. Initial lab results show mild hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. The child Is diagnosed with adrenal Insufficiency and treated appropriately; however, his behavior continues to worsen, and he begins to have difficulty walking and speaking. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of his behavior problems?
questions.solution:
• The most common initial manifestations are hyperactivity, which is often mistaken for an attention deficit disorder, and worsening school performance in a child who had previously been a good student.
  • Impaired cortisol response to ACTH stimulation is present in 85% of patients, and mild hyperpigmentation is noted. In most patients with this phenotype, adrenal dysfunction is recognized only after the condition is diagnosed because of the cerebral symptoms.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 688

questions.text: Which of the following is not a remnant of fetal circulation in a normal child?
questions.solution:
• Remnants of fetal circulation are Ligamentum teres, Ligamentum venosum, Median umbilical ligament and Ligamentum arteriosum.
  • Ostium primum is a defect in ASD.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 2161

questions.text: Following is image of a vaginally delivered 3.5kg with vacuum assistance at 1st hour of life. Spot diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• A scalp swelling crossing the midline and involving multiple scalp bone area is suggestive of caput succedaneum.
  • Cephalhematoma develops later after birth, not cross midline.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 834

choices.text: Bag and mask ventilation and chest compression

questions.text: A 3.2kg newborn is delivered full term vaginally. You are the attending pediatrician for the call. The child did not cry after birth. On delivery, vitals were HR 50/min, RR-jerky shallow breathing, peripherals cyanosed, limbs limp. Which is the next step according to NRP protocol?
questions.solution:
• According to NRP, any child with HR<60 with jerky shallow breathing needs immediate chest compression and bag and mask ventilation at 3:1 ratio for 30 seconds.

Reference: Neonatal Resuscitation program manual, 2016, AAP

questions.text: A 1year 2-month-old child residing in Gujarat, visits you for catch up vaccination. He has been last vaccinated at 3.5 months of age. The parents are adamant to give vaccines only according to National immunization program. Accordingly, which of the vaccines can be given in this visit for catchup vaccination?
questions.solution:
• Typhoid conjugate, Hepatitis A are not included in NIP. Hence, according to NIP next vaccination scheduled after 3.5 months of age is at 9 months of Measles vaccine.

Reference: IAP textbook of immunization

questions.text: A 1-year-old child can do all except
questions.solution:
• At 1 year, child can speak 2 meaningful words.
  • Stand without support at 1 year
  • Pincer grasp matures at 1 year
  • Wave bye-bye at 9 months

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 1st SA ed., pg. 31

choices.text: Send GA-AFB and Chest X ray
Observation if the child develops any symptoms

questions.text: A child was born to a 29-year-old mother who has been diagnosed with TB in 3rd trimester of pregnancy and is on regular AKT since last 1 month. Child on external physical examination is normal. Which of the following should be the next step?
questions.solution:
• An infant born of TB positive mother with no symptoms must be screened for congenital tuberculosis by sending GA-AFB twice and Chest X-ray and also USG abdomen to rule out abdominal Koch.
  • If all screening is negative, child is given INH prophylaxis till 6 months of age.
  • If screenings are positive, then full course of AKT must be given to the child.

Reference: NNF protocol, 2019
